https://prez.dev/description.@value: The form of a sample, i.e. the visible shape or configuration of a geological material. The listing includes both primary samples and derived specimens, that is primary sources (e.g. drillcore, hand specimen) and items resulting from preparation of those source materials for the purpose of research/analytical work (e.g. thin section, fine powder). Artefacts are also included, but in this vocabulary they specifically refer to man-made objects of cultural or historical interest such as a tool or decoration (i.e. items such as thin sections, mounts, etc. are not regarded as artefacts in this context). Descriptions were compiled trying to avoid reference to the material that comprises the specimen (e.g. rock, fossil) or the sampling method (e.g. drilling), although in practice it is not always possible to completely separate these concepts from the sample type (e.g. rotary sidewall core); in fact many of the concepts for sample type and sample materials are (incorrectly) used interchangeably.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The homogeneous, solid body of a chemical element, compound, or isomorphous mixture whose constituents (such as atoms, molecules, or ions) are arranged in a highly ordered microscopic structure, forming an ordered lattice that extends in all directions; this regularly repeating atomic arrangement may be outwardly expressed by plane faces. Although a crystal is characterized first by its definite internal molecular structure and second by its external form, the term is generally used in reference to a mineral specimen that is at least partially defined by its geometrical shape consisting of flat faces with specific, characteristic orientations (i.e. natural external crystalline plane faces).

https://prez.dev/description.@value: The homogeneous, solid body of a chemical element, compound, or isomorphous mixture whose constituents (such as atoms, molecules, or ions) are arranged in a highly ordered microscopic structure, forming an ordered lattice that extends in all directions; this regularly repeating atomic arrangement may be outwardly expressed by plane faces. Although a crystal is characterized first by its definite internal molecular structure and second by its external form, the term is generally used in reference to a mineral specimen that is at least partially defined by its geometrical shape consisting of flat faces with specific, characteristic orientations (i.e. natural external crystalline plane faces).

A group of mineral crystals formed in an open space environment and exhibiting a euhedral crystal form determined by their internal crystal structure; or a specimen derived from it. A cluster of small crystals coating the walls of a cavity is called a druse. From a collecting perspective, crystal cluster can also refer to a group of crystals obtained from the removal of matrix to expose well-formed crystals.

Broken piece(s) of a single crystal or crystal cluster. The breakage process can be either natural (i.e. due to geological factors/events) or artificial (e.g. occurring during sampling or specimen preparation).

In mineralogical terms, a 'floater' is a single crystal or aggregate of crystals that is not attached to a host rock / hard matrix, and has no obvious indication that it has been removed from matrix. All sides of floater crystals are usually fully intact without damage, as they don't have a fractured attachment point. Floaters can form when crystals grow within a matrix that is either soft or subsequently removed (such as from a clay); or it may be a crystal that formed attached to matrix but was subsequently detached during tectonic activity, with the broken attachment point later re-healed or extended by a secondary mineralization event. The term is generally not used for crystals that have been freed from hard matrix, such as garnets removed from schist, whether such removal was natural or artificial. Not to be confused with 'float', a loose rock collected at the surface of the Earth.

A geode is a globular/spherical to irregular mass of resistant mineral matter that is usually hollow and partially to completely filled with crystals. Completely infilled geodes are often referred to as nodules, but the two names are not always consistently used: geodes differ from nodules in that a nodule is a solid mass of mineral matter, but some nodules may have a tiny void space in their interiors and the distinction between a geode and a nodule may be barely discernible if the cavity is miniscule. Geodes differ from vugs in that geodes can be separated free from any matrix, because their walls commonly weather out of rock exposures. Unlike a druse, a geode is separable (by weathering) as a discrete concretion from the rock in which it occurs, and its inner crystals are not of the same minerals as those of the enclosing rock. The crystals lining a geode are formed by the filling of vesicles in volcanic and subvolcanic rocks by minerals deposited from hydrothermal fluids; or by the dissolution of syngenetic concretions and partial filling by the same or other minerals precipitated from water, groundwater, or hydrothermal fluids in sedimentary rocks.

A macroscopic or microscopic crystal usually identifiable by its geometric shape, and consisting of flat faces with specific, characteristic orientations/geometry that reflect its crystalline system of formation; a crystal in which all parts have the same crystallographic orientation and the crystal lattice of the entire sample is continuous and unbroken to the edges of the sample with no grain boundaries.
